newsitem.title: CHINA: Shanghai T-bill repo rates close down, spots up.
newsitem.headline: Shanghai T-bill repo rates close down, spots up.

text.p: Contracts on the treasury bill repurchase market in Shanghai ended down on Wednesday with a technical correction on the domestic A share markets reducing fund demand on the repo market, traders said.
The annual rate for the most active seven-day contract fell to 10 percent from 11.4 percent on Tuesday.
Total turnover of the six-contract market fell sharply to 4.1 million lots from 7.2 million.
One lot is 1,000 yuan face value of treasury bills.
Share prices on both the Shanghai and Shenzhen A share markets fell on Wednesday on a technical correction.
In addition, two spot contracts matured on Tuesday and Wednesday and their redemption added money supply to the repo market, helping push down the rates today, traders said.
But the A share issue of Tianxing Meters Co on the Shenzhen stock exchange today gave some support to the repo rates, prevently them from losing sharply, they said.
There will be two A share issues, one in Shanghai and another in Shenzhen, on Thursday and traders said they expected the issues to push the repo rates up slightly tomorrow.
Contracts on the T-bill spot market in Shanghai ended up across the board on Wednesday.
Traders said fresh liquidity was flowing into the spot market due to redemptions of the two contracts.
A correction on the A share markets also helped some speculative funds to return to the repo market, they said.
The most active 10-year bond that matures in June 2006 rose to 117.85 yuan from 117.40 yuan.
Combined volume of the seven-contract market rose to 2.5 million lots from 1.9 million lots.
Traders said the spot market was likely to rise in the short term with a peak of state debt redemption drawing near. China will redeem 120 billion yuan worth in state debt in 1997.
